ifyes_whichexternal: spring temperature mainly, but also elevation, precipication (they also looked at land cover and other climate variables)
double_entry: no study is not very relevant
big_problems: The study didn't really look at direct metrics of growth or growing season so not really. They didn't explicitly look at growing season length but did examine spring temp and productivty. I though it was cool that they looked at productivity in spring but also in summer and fall separatelt and were able to find lags that were somewhat explained by elevation and precipiation

study_scale: 1 site in monitoring network inner-alpine Swiss Rhône valley
big_problems: This study measured gsl, but only to look at the effect on growth of exogenous factors (soil moisture). It's not really looking at GSLxGrowth relationships
missing_something_major: I think they have to dat to start looking at GSLXgrowth too, but not sure why they didn’t

study_scale: 3 sites along elevational gradient and 80 individuals
gsl_start_metric: snow meltout and snow free growing degree days
excellent_study: They didn’t explicitly look at GSL, but they did use snow melt out and snow free growing degree days as a proxy. If we believe this is a good proxy for start of growing season for this shrub then the paper was good and looked at variation in response to cliamte across elevations too. I just wish they had explicitly also looked at leaf phenology to describe growing season onset
notes: the paper is only about SOS and not about GSL, but they did find relationship between SOS and growth (fig 5)
